newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela's bankrupt Viasa may re-fly with Pan Am.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela's bankrupt Viasa may re-fly with Pan Am.

text.p: Bankrupt Venezuelan carrier Viasa may fly again under a proposed $50 million joint venture with U.S.-based Pan Am Corp, former Viasa pilots said.

"We have estimated the project will require an investment of between $30 and $50 million, but it all depends on what the (Venezuelan) government decides to do with the old Viasa routes and planes," William Bracho, head of the Viasa pilots' association Provia, told Reuters.
Pan Am, which operates daily flights within the U.S., Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic, would take a 49 percent stake the project, which still requires government approval, Bracho added.

Viasa was declared bankrupt in February after its principal shareholders -- the Venezuelan government and Spanish state-owned carrier Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espana SA -- failed to convince workers to accept a rescue plan that involved job cuts and route reductions.
